topics.name: Simple Interest
topics.description: Interest calculated on the principal only using the formula: $SI=\dfrac{P\times T\times R}{100}$
topics.hint: Convert time to years and rate to percent before applying the formula.

topics.name: Compound Interest
topics.description: Interest calculated on principal and accumulated interest using the formula: $A=P\left(1+\dfrac{R}{100}\right)^T$
topics.hint: Amount = Principal × (1 + rate/100)^time. CI = Amount - Principal.

topics.name: Profit and Loss
topics.description: Calculations involving Cost Price (CP), Selling Price (SP), Profit, Loss, and percentages.
topics.hint: Profit = SP - CP (when SP > CP), Loss = CP - SP (when CP > SP). Profit% = (Profit/CP) × 100.

topics.name: Simple Interest & Compound Interest
topics.description: Master Simple Interest and Compound Interest calculations. Learn formulas, solve real-world problems, and understand the key differences.
topics.hint: SI uses $SI=\dfrac{P\times T\times R}{100}$. CI uses $A=P\left(1+\dfrac{R}{100}\right)^T$.

questions.question: If the principal amount is ₹1000, the rate of interest is 10%, and the time period is 2 years, what is SI?
questions.explanation:
The formula for finding SI is $\dfrac{PTR}{100}$, where $P,T,$ and $R$ are principal amount, time period, and rate of interest, respectively.

Here,

$P=₹1000$

$T=2$ years

$R=10\%$.

Then, $SI=\dfrac{PTR}{100}=\dfrac{1000	imes 2	imes 10}{100}=200$.

Therefore, SI = ₹200.

questions.question: Find the SI, if an amount of ₹1500 is deposited for 80 days on a scheme that offers a rate of interest of 7.3% per annum.
questions.explanation:
The formula for finding SI is $\dfrac{PTR}{100}$, where $P,T,$ and $R$ are principal amount, time period, and rate of interest, respectively.

Here, the time period is given in days, and the rate of interest is in terms of per annum. Then, the formula for finding SI will be :

$SI=\dfrac{PTR}{365	imes 100}$.

Now,

$P=₹1500$

$T=80$ days

$R=7.3\%$.

Then,

$SI=\dfrac{PTR}{365	imes 100}=\dfrac{1500	imes80	imes7.3}{365	imes100}=₹24$.

Therefore, the SI earned is ₹24.

questions.question: A sum becomes ₹4400 in 2 years and ₹5000 in 5 years. Then, what will be rate of interest?
questions.explanation:
Given that, the sum becomes ₹4400 in 2 years and ₹5000 in years.

Then, the interest obtained for 3 years $= 5000 - 4400 = ₹600$.

That is, the interest for 1 year $=\dfrac{600}{3}=₹200$.

Now, we know that the sum becomes ₹4400 in 2 years, and ₹200 will be the interest on the principal amount for 1 year.

Then, the interest for 2 years $=200+200=₹400$.

Now, the principal amount$=4400-400=₹4000$.

Now, use the formula for SI with $P=₹4000,T=1$year, and $R$ as the rate of interest.

$SI=\dfrac{PTR}{100}$.

$200=\dfrac{4000	imes 1	imes R}{100}$

$R=5\%$.

That is, the rate of interest, $R=5\%$.

questions.question: If the principal amount is ₹5000, the rate of interest is 20%, and the time period is 2 years, what is CI?
questions.explanation:
The formula for finding CI is $P\left(1+\dfrac{R}{100}ight)^T-P$, where $P,T,$ and $R$ are principal amount, time period, and rate of interest, respectively.

Given that, 

$P=₹5000$

$T=2$ years

$R=20\%$.

Then,

$ egin{aligned}
CI&=P\left(1+\dfrac{R}{100}ight)^T-P\
&=5000\left(1+\dfrac{20}{100}ight)^2-5000\
&=5000	imes\left(\dfrac{6}{5}ight)^2-5000\
&=7200-5000\
&=₹2200.

\end{aligned}$

Therefore, the $CI=₹2200.$

questions.question: An amount of ₹10000 at 8% per annum. If the interest is compounded half-yearly, then what is the total interest earned by at the end of  first year?
questions.explanation:
If interest is compounded half-yearly, then the interest is calculated every 6 months.  

That is, rate of interest $= \dfrac{8}{2}= 4\%$ (because the given rate of interest is $8\%$ per annum).  
 
Amount after 6 months $= 10,000 +4\%$ of $10,000$ 
$=₹10,400$.  
Amount after 1 year $= 10,400 +4\%$ of $10,400$
$= ₹10816$.  
Then, the interest earned $=10816-10000=₹816$.

questions.question: A sum of ₹5000 will amount to ₹8640 in 3 years, if the interest is calculated annually. Then, the rate of compound interest is:
questions.explanation:
Amount compounted for $T$ years at a rate of interest of $R\%$ is $P\left(1+\dfrac{R}{100}ight)^T$.

Given that,

$ egin{aligned}
8640&=5000\left(1+\dfrac{R}{100}ight)^3\
\dfrac{8640}{5000}&=\left(1+\dfrac{R}{100}ight)^3\
\dfrac{\sqrt[3]{216}}{\sqrt[3]{125}}&=\left(1+\dfrac{R}{100}ight)\
\dfrac{6}{5}-1&=\dfrac{R}{100}\implies R=20\%.
\end{aligned}$

Therefore, the rate of interest is $20\%$.

questions.question: By how much does CI exceed SI on ₹3000 at 10% for 2 years?
If the simple interest is 12% annually and the compound interest is 10% annually, find the difference between the interests after 3 years on a sum of ₹4000.
The difference between the compound interest and the simple interest on a certain sum at 12% per annum for two years is ₹810. What is the principal amount?
questions.explanation:
Given that, the difference between the compound interest and the simple interest at 12% per annum on a certain sum for a time period of 2 years is ₹810.

Let $P$ be the principal amount. Then, $R=12\%$ and $T=2$ years.

$SI=\dfrac{PTR}{100}=\dfrac{2	imes12 P}{100}=\dfrac{6P}{25}$

$ egin{aligned}
CI&=P\left(\left(1+\dfrac{R}{100}ight)^T-1ight)\
&=P\left(\left(1+\dfrac{12}{100}ight)^2-1ight)\
&=P\left(\dfrac{6}{25}+\dfrac{3^2}{25^2}ight).
\end{aligned}$

Then,

$810=CI - SI = \dfrac{9P}{625}$ 

$20=\dfrac{P}{625}\implies P=₹12500$.

Therefore, the principal amount, $P=₹12500$.

questions.question: A shopkeeper bought a book for Rs.20 and sold it for Rs.25. What is the profit or loss the shopkeeper made?
questions.explanation:
Given, CP = 20 and SP = 25

As we know, 

Profit = SP - CP 

Profit = 25 - 20 = 5

Hence, shopkeeper made profit of  Rs. 5.

questions.question: A person bought a Bag from the shopkeeper for Rs.50, which cost the shopkeeper Rs.25. How much extra does an extra person is paying compared to the original cost price in percentage?
questions.explanation:
Given, SP = 50, and CP = 25

The extra money person is spending is profit to shopkeeper

Profit = SP - CP 

Profit = 50 - 25 = 25

In percentage, Profit = $\dfrac{25}{25} 	imes 100$ = 100%

Hence, the person is paying 100% extra on original cost price.

questions.question: Ravi sold his old vehicle to his friend for a 20% profit. The car cost Ravi Rs.1570, so what is the price Ravi's friend paid for the car?
questions.explanation:
Given, Profit % = 20% and CP = 1570

We know, Profit = SP - CP \quad 	o (1)

$	ext{Profit \%} = \dfrac{	ext{Profit}}{	ext{CP}} 	imes 100 \Rightarrow 	ext{Profit} = \dfrac{	ext{Profit\%} 	imes 	ext{CP}}{100}$ 

Profit = $\dfrac{20 	imes 1570}{100}$ = 314

Now substitute Profit values in the Eq (1)

314 = SP - 1570

 SP = 314 + 1570 = 1884

 Hence, Ravi paid for the car price of Rs.1884 .

questions.question: Vivek bought a book at a marked price of Rs.X, which cost the shopkeeper Rs.12. What is the marked price if the profit for the shopkeeper on CP is 25% and it was sold for Rs.5 less than the marked price?
questions.explanation:
Given, CP = 12, Profit% = 250% and Discount =  Rs.5

SP = CP + Profit

$	ext{Profit \%} = \dfrac{	ext{Profit}}{	ext{CP}} 	imes 100 \Rightarrow 	ext{Profit} = \dfrac{	ext{Profit\%} 	imes 	ext{CP}}{100}$ 

Profit = $\dfrac{250 	imes 12}{100}$ = 30

SP = 12 + 30 = 42

MP = SP + Discount

MP = 42 + 5 = 47

Therefore, marked price of the book is  Rs.47.

questions.question: Rahul sold his old bike at Rs.2500, which cost him Rs.1750. However, he marked 50% higher on the Cost Price when selling. What is the Marked Price?
questions.explanation:
Given, SP = 2500 and CP = 1750.

By given condition, MP = 50 % CP + CP

= $\left(\dfrac{50}{100} 	imes 1750 ight)+ 1750$

= 875 + 1750 = 2625

Hence, the marked price on the bike was  Rs.2625.

questions.question: A vendor marked his goods at 30% higher than the Selling Price, and he sold them at a 25% profit on the Cost Price. What is the Selling Price of the goods if he marked the goods at Rs.130?
questions.explanation:
Given, vendor marked good 30% more than SP

Profit % = 25 and marked price (MP) = 130

MP = SP + Discount 

Here Discount = 30% of SP = 0.3 SP

MP = 1.3 SP

130 = 1.3 SP

SP = $\dfrac{130}{1.3}$ = $\dfrac{1300}{13}$ = 100

Hence, the selling price of the goods is  Rs.100.

questions.question: A bookkeeper sold a bundle of books at a 25% profit. Moreover, the bundle cost him Rs.132. Then what is the selling price?
questions.explanation:
Given, Profit % = 25 and CP = 132

We know, SP = CP + Profit

$	ext{Profit \%} = \dfrac{	ext{Profit}}{	ext{CP}} 	imes 100 \Rightarrow 	ext{Profit} = \dfrac{	ext{Profit\%} 	imes 	ext{CP}}{100}$ 

Profit = $\dfrac{25 	imes 132}{100}$ = 33

SP = CP + Profit = 132 + 33 = 165

Hence, the selling price of bundle of books is  Rs.165.

questions.question: A bookkeeper sold a bundle of books at 33% profit, and the cost price is 75%of 132. Then what is the selling price?
questions.explanation:
Given, Profit % = 33 and CP = 75 % of 132

CP = $\dfrac{75}{100} 	imes 132$ = 99

CP = 99

SP = CP + Profit

$	ext{Profit} = \dfrac{	ext{Profit\%} 	imes 	ext{CP}}{100}$

Profit = $\dfrac{33 	imes 99}{100}$ = 32.67

SP = 99 + 32.67 = 131.67

Hence, the selling price is 131.67.

questions.question: Amit sold his Car and Bike due to financial issues. On the Car, which cost him Rs.5000, he got a 20% profit. On the Bike, which cost him Rs.2500, he incurred a loss of Rs.500. What is his overall profit or loss from these transactions?
questions.explanation:
Given, $CP_1$ = 5000, $CP_2$ = 2500

Profit % on Car = 20%

Loss on Bike = 500

Profit on Car = 20% of $CP_1$ + $CP_1$

= $\left(\dfrac{20}{100} 	imes 5000 ight)$ = 1000 

Which means, 

$SP_1$ = 5000 + 1000 = 6000

$SP_2$ = 2500 - 500 = 2000

CP = $CP_1$ + $CP_2$ = 5000 + 2500 = 7500

SP = $SP_1$ + $SP_2$ = 6000 + 2000 = 8000

Profit = SP - CP = 8000 - 7500 = 500

Hence, Amit made a profit on these transactions of 500.
